item.title: Walking through the delta method
item.description: Imagine weâ€™ve constructed an estimator \(T_n\) for some parameter \(\theta\) but what we really want to know about is \(\phi(\theta)\), some transformation of the parameter. Can we use our knowledge of the behavior of \(T_n\) to learn about \(\phi(T_n)\)? By the continuous-mapping theorem if \(\phi\) is continuous then: if \(T_n \to \theta\) then \(\phi(T_n) \to \phi(\theta)\) By the delta method we have if \(\sqrt{n}(T_n - \theta) \rightsquigarrow T\) as \(n \to \infty\) then \(\sqrt{n}(\phi(T_n) - \phi(\theta)) \rightsquigarrow \phi'_\theta(T)\) where \(\phi'_\theta(T) = \phi'(\theta)*T\).
